item.title: Gallery for R graphs and charts
item.description:
R is a great tool for data visualization. The native tool becomes even better thanks to external packages such as ggplot2 that are widely used in the gallery. If you’re wondering what you can do with R in terms of dataviz, the following online resources may help you.

From Data to Viz is a classification of chart types based on input data format. It comes in the form of a decision tree leading to a set of potentially appropriate visualizations to represent the dataset. The project is built on two underlying philosophies. First, that most data analysis can be summarized in about twenty different dataset formats. Second, that both data and context determine the appropriate chart. Thus, From Data to Viz suggested method consists in identifying and trying all feasible chart types to find out which suits your data and idea best. Once this set of graphics is identified, From Data to Viz aims to guide you toward the best decision. It also provides a list of common caveats to avoid and always provides a reproducible code snippet in the R programming language. Dataviz is a world with endless possibilities and this project does not claim to be exhaustive. However, it should provide you with a good starting point.

The R CHARTS web site has been created without any financial support by Jos√© Carlos Soage. It was generated with blogdown, an R package which allows creating static web sites using the HUGO generator. The theme of this site is a custom theme inspired by Kross and Academic themes. The classification of the charts is based on the Financial Times visual vocabulary. On the site of R CHARTS you will find code examples of R graphs made with base R graphics, ggplot2 and other R package.

R graph gallery is a collection of charts made with the R programming language. Charts are organized by family and types. Hundreds (~ 400 charts) of charts are displayed in several sections, always with their reproducible code and explanations available. The gallery makes a focus on the tidyverse and ggplot2. For each chart, a focus is made on code, but a link toward data-to-viz is provided to give more information concerning the theory.

item.title: R project and commonly used packages
item.description:
R is a free software environment for statistical computing and graphics. It is the most widely used language for data science, together with python. The R Project for Statistical Computing provide multiple CRAN Mirrors to Download R. In China mainland, at least 10 mirror sites are available, such as those of USTC, LZU, SUSTech. Pick whatever one seems closest to you and start your work.

Rtools : Toolchains for building R and R package from source on Windows.

RStudio is also hepful and friendly supplement for R and can be downloaded by click the names.

RStudio Connect is the best way to host and share data products made with R and Python.

ggplot2 is a R package dedicated to create Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis. It can greatly improve the quality and aesthetics of your graphics, and will make you much more efficient in creating them. ggplot2 allows to build almost any type of chart ans is avaliable on GitHub as well.

Complex heatmaps are efficient to visualize associations between different sources of data sets and reveal potential patterns. Here the ComplexHeatmap package provides a highly flexible way to arrange multiple heatmaps and supports self-defined annotation graphics.

Bioconductor uses the R statistical programming language, and is open source and open development. It has two releases each year, and an active user community. Bioconductor is also available as Docker images. The mission of the Bioconductor project is to develop, support, and disseminate free open source software that facilitates rigorous and reproducible analysis of data from current and emerging biological assays. We are dedicated to building a diverse, collaborative, and welcoming community of developers and data scientists.

Biomedical Knowledge Mining using GOSemSim and clusterProfiler is meant as a guide for mining biological knowledge to elucidate or interpret molecular mechanisms using a suite of R package, including ChIPseeker, clusterProfiler, DOSE, enrichplot, GOSemSim, meshes and ReactomePA.

The WGCNA R software package is a comprehensive collection of R functions for performing various aspects of weighted correlation network analysis. The package includes functions for network construction, module detection, gene selection, calculations of topological properties, data simulation, visualization, and interfacing with external software. Click here to access the tutorial page.
